introMethod1.value:
Your high school yearbook photo is
a moment frozen in time. For some, it’s a moment they’d rather forget, but for us, it’s data.

introMethod2.value: We investigated a dataset of more than 30,000 high school yearbook photos from 1930–2013 to find out when big hair was at its height.

dimensionText1.value:
Using a deep learning method,
we mapped the images into
a 4-dimensional space.

dimensionText2.value: This gives us a unique fingerprint for each hair shape. Here’s what that looks like for 3 popular styles...

styleText1.value: We then trained neural network classifiers to see how these looks trended over time.

straightText.value: Long straight hair was briefly eclipsed by 1980s perms.

avgGridText1.value: From here, we can investigate when big hair peaked. Here are 10 photos that best exemplify the women’s and men’s hairstyles of each decade...

avgGridText2.value:
Here’s what that looks like
when we split it by gender…

trendText1.value: By calculating the density of hair pixels in each picture, we can roughly estimate how much hair is present and get a median hair size for each decade.

trendNote1.value: Women’s hair was the shortest in the 1930s, when short finger waves were popular.

trendNote2.value: Men’s hair was the shortest in the decades following World War II, when many sported military crew cuts.

trendNote3.value: For both women and men, hair size peaked in the late 70s and early 80s.

trendText2.value: All that big hair also meant that women and men’s styles were more similar than ever before.

discrimNote1.value: Women and men’s hairstyles saw their biggest difference post WWII when short buzzes were contrasted with high roll curls.

discrimNote2.value: They saw their smallest difference in the 1980s when big hairspray reigned supreme.

discrimNote3.value: In 2013, women’s and men’s styles were less similiar than anytime in the past 30 years.

outro1.value: This doesn’t mean that gender neutral hairstyles are less common, just that there are more polarizing styles like long or short crops.

outro2.value: Whatever the style trends, we’re all sure to laugh at our photos in the next decade.
